prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our observation intends to observe the spatial distribution of the [CI] 3P1-3P0 (492.1607 GHz; Band 8) line in the circumnuclear ring (CND) orbiting the central supermassive blackhole Sgr A*.
1. Required resolution and sensitivity
There is no available synthesis imaging data of 500 GHz [CI] line toward the Galactic center, and its spatial distribution and intensity is totally unknown. Therefore, as the first attempt of imaging of this line, we will observe the largest spatial structure possible with the ALMA spec. We request a spatial resolution of 1.52 arcsec, i.e., twice the synthesized beamsize with the most compact 12 m configuration. The smallest structure of the target detected with the previous observations (including ALMA data) is of 1 arcsec scale, and hence our resolution requirement is sufficiently high to detect all known molecular cloud features. The required velocity resolution is 5 km/s, because the velocity width of our target is known to be 20-100 km/s in FWHM (Montero-Castano 2009). We assume the typical intensity of the target line to be 0.7 K for the 2 pc-ring of the CND, as justified below. From single dish observations with the ASTE 10 m telescope, the [CI] 3P1-3P0 to HCN J=4-3 intensity ratio is measured to be ~1 for the CND. Considering a possibility that the [CI] line is more spatially extended and more flux is resolved-out, we assume the [CI] 3P1-3P0 to HCN J=4-3 ratio to be 0.5 for the ALMA observation. The synthesis observation by Montero-Castano (2009) detected HCN J=4-3 emission with 2 Jy/beam (4".6 x 3".0 beamsize) for wide spatial range, which is 1.4 K in the brightness temperature scale. Therefore we expect the [CI] intensity to be 0.7 K on average. The emission may suffer more missing flux for the v_LSR range from 0 to 60 km/s, where the emission from CND overlaps with the extended emission in the background and foreground, but we may expect the missing flux is satisfactorily recovered by the ACA.
Based on this estimate, we request a sensitivity of 0.14 K (or 64 mJy) so that the major part of the target can be detected above 5 sigma-level. If the achieved S/N ratio is below this expectation, which is possible for the emission inside the 2 pc-ring, we can improve the S/N ratio by up a factor of 2-4 depending on the linewidth, by binning velocity channels.
2. Imaging
Spatial extension of the target is about 140 arcsec times 100 arcsec in diameters. In order to cover this area with minimum number of pointings, we request sub-Nyquist mosaicing of elliptical field shown in Figure 3. Separation between each pointing is set to 1^(1/2) times of the beam FWHM, i.e., maximum separation allowed with the standard observation mode. We do not adopt Nyquist-sampled mosaicing, because it would require 315 pointings and total observation time of 12 hours to cover the region with the our sensitivity requirement. Even with our sub-Nyquist mosaicing, sensitivity fluctuation of the resultant map is less then 10 % across the whole field of view. We request use of the ACA system, because the maximum spatial scale of the source (about 30 arcsec) is larger than the maximum recoverable scale of the 12 m-array in the most compact configuration. Based on the requirements for the sensitivity and for the imaging, the total observation time is estimated to be 5.2 hours by the OT time estimator, including the additional time for the use of the ACA system. This observation time is well within a reasonable range, even considering the difficulty in observations in the Band 8.
3. Correlator setup
We request the 1875 MHz bandwidth mode for the correlator setup, which offers velocity resolution of 0.595 km/s and velocity coverage of 1142 km/s. This is sufficient to cover the full velocity distribution of the neutral and ionized gas in the observed regions, namely, -300 km/s to +300 km/s. The velocity resolution is also sufficient as stated in the section 1.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Accretion of the molecular gas toward the Galactic nucleus Sgr A* controls the nuclear activity and star formation in the circumnuclear region. However, distribution and physical conditions of the molecular gas in the central few parsecs remain unknown in many aspects, such as at how close distance to the nucleus molecular gas survives, and whether they are capable of forming stars against the tidal disruption in the strong gravity field. Our recent observations of the atomic carbon (C^0) [CI] line have detected a molecular cloud with unusually high C^0 abundance, which have been unrecognized with previous molecular line observations. This `[CI]-cloud' is a key to understand how the molecular mass is supplied to the star formation in the central few parsecs, because the majority of the molecular mass in and around the circumnuclear disk (CND) is occupied by this C^0-rich molecular gas. The C^0/CO abundance ratio is over unity, and hence C^0, instead of CO, is the most fundamental tracer of molecular mass. We propose a [CI] imaging of the central 5 parsec region of the Galactic center, to investigate the molecular mass distribution and mass accretion in and inside the CND.
